item.title: Next Steps
item.description: Ideas for next steps inlude Further refinement of existing sonification techniques Exploration of further sonification techniques and musical patterns that can be employed for auditory representation of data Website expansion, including a user-interactive interface which allows the user to upload data, select instruments, and create their own sonified datasets Publication

Initial Musical Aims
item.description: Music is an emotionally-charged medium. It has the power to elicit strong emotional reactions from the listener through various musical techniques and patterns. As listeners, our reactions to different musical sounds are a product of the musical culture with which we are familiar. For example, in the Western Classical tradition, major tonalities are associated with happiness, positivity, and optimism, whereas minor tonalities are associated with sadness, negativity, and pessimism. Similarly, consonance is associated with beauty, levity, and relief, whereas dissonance is associated with conflict, anger, and tension.

item.title: About the Data
item.description: Origin This data was taken from Interdialytic weight gain, systolic blood pressure, serum albumin, and C-reactive protein levels change in chronic dialysis patients prior to death (Usvyat et al., 2013) Data Manipulation and Music Generation Took a 5-week rolling average to smooth out the data Re-scaled the values between 0 and 1 Presented the values in chronological order, representing weeks leading to death Assigned each clinical parameter to an instrument of a different type Created instrumentation files based on musical aims Algorithmically generated a musical sequence strictly based on the data presented, using the instrumentaion files created
